media:group.media:title: Azerbaijan detains senior Karabakh officials
media:group.media:description:
üìçAzerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev pulled out of talks planned for tomorrow with Armenian Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan and the leaders of France, Germany, and the EU. üìçTop officials from the EU, U.S., and Russia met in Turkey for previously undisclosed emergency talks on Karabakh just days before Azerbaijan launched its offensive last month, Politico reported. üìçFrance plans to sell weapons to Armenia, the two countries‚Äô foreign ministers confirmed. üìçArmenia‚Äôs parliament voted to join the International Criminal Court, ignoring repeated and unusually strong warnings from Russia about the consequences of doing so. üìçAzerbaijan detained former Karabakh Presidents Arkadi Ghukasyan, Bako Sahakyan, and Arayik Harutyunyan, as well as Davit Ishkanyan, the ex-parliament speaker. üìçKristinne Grigoryan, Armenia‚Äôs former human rights defender, will head the country‚Äôs newly formed Foreign Intelligence Service.
Credits: Ruptly

media:group.media:title: CivilNet‚Äôs Karabakh team arrives safely in Yerevan
media:group.media:description:
üìçThe total number of people who have fled from Karabakh to Armenia now stands at more than 100,000. That represents nearly all of the region‚Äôs population. üìçAt least four high-ranking Karabakh officials have been detained by Azerbaijan so far, including the businessman and philanthropist Ruben Vardanyan. üìçA United Nations mission reached Karabakh, marking the first time in about three decades the organization has had access to the region. üìçCatherine Colonna, France‚Äôs foreign minister, is set to visit Armenia.
